lexUnit.name: chew.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: bite and work (food) in the mouth to make it easier to swallow.

sentence.text: He chewed ribs of grass and swallowed green saliva .
It chewed the bloody snow , gulped the entrails and the gore , growled in its throat as it worked at the tough tissues .
He has also chewed three torches , three combs , two hair brushes , and my bed linen .
Blanche paused and chewed her bottom lip .
Luce chewed her underlip and stared into space .
She chewed paan from an elaborately incised silver box .
All patients received aspirin ( 162 mg daily ) and the first dose was chewed for rapid and full antithrombotic effect .
It was chewing the rope with its ugly yellow teeth .
Sue filled her mouth with houmus and chewed silently for a moment .
It was as good as a ballet to watch Finn eat but Francie mopped gravy with bread and chewed bones from his fingers .
He would redden suddenly , for no apparent reason , and chew the skin at the side of his thumb-nail .
Riven chewed bread which had turned to sand in his mouth .
She would chew her clothes , her bedclothes , her teddy , furniture materials , and the foam stuffing .
If it is dry and unyielding we automatically chew it until it becomes comfortable to swallow .
KƒÅli came to bring me some of the cooked meat , chewing some herself .
I have some sheet music which belonged to my mother , unless the mice and rats at Low Birk Hatt have chewed it to bits .
She chewed her lip distractedly .
Rubberneck chewed his fingernails ; they were long bony fingers , bitten to the quick .
She smiled and chewed and chewed and smiled
He chewed and smiled and cuffed a little run of juice off his chin with the heel of one hand .
He chewed Downing 's thumb nearly off before they could master him .
